climbs.name: Wham, Jam, Thank You Cam
climbs.fa: Doug Reilly and Robert Romanowicz, May 1992

content.description: Walk a short way up a faint use trail on the far left side of Chain Reaction Buttress (left of Nameless Arete). Go up a left-facing dihedral for most of the cliff; near the top, traverse left to a tree, then top out.

climbs.name: No Self Control
climbs.fa: Warren Musselman and John Anderson, Oct 1981

content.description: Follows a large corner, sometimes sharing it with a little trickling water or toxic foliage. Halfway up is a ledge with a tree, and it tops out through a notch, slightly to the right in a small overhang.
content.protection:
Rack. Easy to protect.

 No anchor/rap bolts over this route, though the bolts from neighboring routes can be borrowed if nobody else is on the east side of Chain Reaction Buttress.
content.location: Far right/east side of Chain Reaction Buttress, starting from the belay trail.

content.description: Climb up to the ledge with the stump and crank out the crimpy moves past 3 bolts culminating with a deadpoint to a jug, the difficulty then backs off, pass a two shuts anchor on a ledge and continue 10 feet to the top and clip the chains.
content.protection: 3 bolts, a pair of cold shuts, then the chains.
content.location: The Arete on the left hand side of the Chain Reaction Buttress

content.description: These climbs are just around the corner from Chain Reaction. The inside corner is the 5.4 with var. on the facing wall both moving a little more left each time. The corner and first var. are easy to protect although the corner is a a little dirty at times. Fun in general.
content.protection: Bolts at top. Standard rack. Bolts were not placed at the first ascent
content.location: Go past Phone Booth look in front of you by narrow part in trail.

climbs.name: Deaf and Dumb (variation 1)
climbs.fa: Warren Musselman and Andrew Lust, Fall 1981

content.description: Variation 1 is on the wall left of the 5.4 route, moving a little more left as it climbs. It goes left to the final overhang, then angles right to the notch to the right.
content.protection:
2 bolts at top. Standard rack. 

  My guidebook gives the protection as "PG/R".
content.location: Just around the corner from Chain Reaction.

climbs.name: Chain Reaction
climbs.fa: Colin Lantz, Warren Mussleman, Andrew Lust, Oct 1984

content.description: We start this a little different then the book describes by simply starting off the trail. Go straight up first block to nice ledge where the Nameless Arete starts. Continue straight up the graffiti section about 10 feet off ledge is the crux you pull and awkward mantel then reach for small crimpers above you. Continue straight up to big roof. Holds are there but sometimes you have to reach and get keep them feet on.
content.protection: Bolts and chains at top. This can be lead but is run out and gear is marginal.

climbs.name: Blind and Deaf
climbs.fa: Warren Musselman and Andrew Lust, Fall 1981.

content.description: Also known as Deaf and Dumb variation 2. Starts as Deaf and Dumb, at a left-facing corner. It heads out left across the face around a nose, and up over an overhang with loose chips of rock.
content.protection: Bolts or bolts and chains at top, depending on which anchor is used. We found it easier to toprope this off the Chain Reaction anchor, not the Deaf and Dumb anchor.
content.location: Between Chain Reaction and Deaf and Dumb.

content.description: First climb short bulging face. The crux is after the first ledge. When you pull the overhang on to the steep slab, the book notes that if you fall from the steep slab the bolts won't stop you from hitting the ledge. You now can top rope this with new chains and bolts at top.
content.location: 12 feet right of Deaf and Dumb. Start up where the path is narrowest. Fire straight up.

content.description: Sunny most of the day. When Phone booth is crowded it is normally got a few great lines open. Some of the climbs here can be super fun and challenging. Nameless Arete 10c is a tough sport climb. A lot of climbs now have bolts and chains at the top for less impact on the trees and natural features. It makes climbing here much safer and quicker. Unfortunately it also brings more people and less experienced climbers, it can get busy on weekends.
